data.title: Engineering News-Record
data.meta_description: Check out the March 25, 2024 edition of ENR, featuring cutting edge tech deployed for the Portland Airport expansion, Safety Report, news and more!
data.text:
Safety and Health

Bechtel to Invest $7M for Construction Suicide Prevention

Contribution is largest donation from a single donor in American Foundation for Suicide Prevention's history

Global contractor launches five-year link with suicide prevention foundation to reduce high number of suicide-caused deaths in construction, a "shameful statistic," said CEO Brendan Bechtel.

Read More

Public Agencies Discuss Evolution of Alternative Project Delivery Methods

Attendees at the Western Winter Workshop heard lessons learned on CMAR, PDB.

Read More

Engineer Cites Benefits of $6B Texas Storm Surge Protection Proposal

Walter P Moore and Associates expert says the project, which the firm and Rice University are designing, involves constructing an island chain to protect industry in the Houston Ship Channel from hurricane impact.

Read More

Federal Projects

Record Funding, Big Contract Award Set to Push Hanford Cleanup

Most complex DOE nuclear waste site remediation seeks record $3.1B funding for fiscal 2025 as core 10-year management contact is finally awarded after long bidding dispute.

Read More

Codes and Standards

US Dept. of Energy Updates Commercial Building Model Energy Standard

Buildings that meet the newer ANSI/ASHRAE/IES Standard 90.1-2022 would see an average of 9.8% in site energy savings compared to those that only meet the 2019 standard, an agency analysis estimates.

Read More

$1.5B Rail Facility Construction Set to Begin at Port of Long Beach

The Pier B On-Dock Rail Support Facility project will directly connect to on-dock rail facilities and the Alameda Corridor railway.

Read More

Design Professional Liability Insurers: Brace for More Price Hikes

A survey by broker Ames & Gough notes planned increases for the third consecutive year.

Read More

Manufacturing

Rivian Pauses $5B Electric Vehicle Plant in Georgia

Automaker will gear up to produce its small EV SUV at an existing Illinois plant instead.

Read More

Transportation

Portland, Ore.'s I-5 Rose Quarter Project Secures $450M Grant, Key Environmental Approval

The project project will add auxiliary lanes to Interstate 5 through the city and construct a highway cover to support reconnection of the city’s Albina community to the downtown.

Read More

Transportation

NYC Pledges Funds to Port Authority's $10B Manhattan Bus Terminal

City officials commit 40 years of tax revenue from three potential commercial developments

Major replacement and expansion is due for the 73-year-old interstate transit hub on Manhattan's west side.

Read More

Investigations

Probe Says Surfside Pool Deck Failed Several Minutes Before Building

Investigators still seek initiating event of fatal Champlain Towers South failure

The National Institute of Standards and Technology expects to publish a draft report on its investigation in May 2025.

Read More

Water Projects

Panama Canal Proposes New Reservoir to Secure Water Supply

Proposed $900M project could be completed in five years to alleviate water shortage transit impacts, canal officials say, but the Panama government must first approve measures to enable construction start

Read More

Federal Funding

Congress Nears Passage of Major Spending Measure With Funds for Construction and Infrastructure

The six-bill package includes DOT, EPA, Corps of Engineers, VA, DOE and military construction funding for the rest of fiscal year 2024.

Read More

Highway Infrastructure

FHWA Seeks to Drop Manufactured Products' Buy America Waiver

The agency aims to strengthen U.S. manufacturers and boost jobs, but removing the 40-year-old general waiver has drawn criticism from industry groups.

Read More

Worker Safety and Health

EPA Finalizes Rule Banning Ongoing Uses of Asbestos

The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency has issued a final rule prohibiting ongoing uses of chrysotile asbestos, the only known form of asbestos currently imported, processed or distributed for use in the U.S.

Read More

Renewable Energy

Orsted Cuts Offshore Wind Target, Exits Some Non-US Markets

The Danish offshore wind developer reduced its 2030 renewable energy capacity goal from 50 GW to 35-38 GW.

Read More

Renewable Energy

Alberta Restricts New Clean Power Projects on Most Farm Land

Canada's largest onshore wind energy project narrowly escaped new provincial law

About $8B of proposed wind and solar projects may be at risk under the new province edict, but 500-MW Buffalo Plains onshore wind generator is set to operate by year-end.

Read More

Construction Workforce

Construction Adds 23,000 Jobs in February for 11th Straight Monthly Gain

Heavy and civil engineering construction was the strongest sector, adding 12,500 positions in February.

Read More

Biden Touts Infrastructure, Manufacturing Growth in State of the Union

Most of President Joe Biden’s March 7 speech to a joint session of Congress centered on domestic issues, but he also announced one construction-related overseas action.

Read More

Federal Funding

Biden Budget Seeks Heavy Spending for DOT, Corps Construction

The proposal includes new $8-billion, five-year program to upgrade FAA facilities, radar systems.

Read More

What's Needed for Engineering Plan Review Success

A commentary about seeing what's missing and what's present when it shouldn’t be.

Read More

Industry Leads for the Week of March 25, 2024

Information derived from Industrial Reports, a market intelligence firm specializing in industrial construction and equipment leads.

Read More

Construction History

River Flow Reversed to Solve Sewage Problem for Chicago

During the 19th century, Chicago’s sewage got dumped into the Chicago River and flowed into Lake Michigan. Because the city’s drinking water was, and still is, drawn from the lake via two mile-long tunnels, officials feared that the sewage would endanger the water supply.

Read More

Interviews

Ten Minutes With Grant Quasha, CEO of Eco Material

Grant Quasha is the CEO of Eco Material, a leading producer and supplier of cement products using selective cementitious materials (SCMs) and other alternative material sources. The company has made significant investments in recent years to expand its supply of SCMs beyond traditional sources of waste materials produced by coal-fired power plants. Quasha spoke with ENR about the current and future prospects for alternative materials in the cement supply chain.

Read More

Black & Veatch Establishes Global Cybersecurity Practice

Engineer Black & Veatch has brought on Ian Bramson as its vice president of global industrial cybersecurity.

Read More

Information Technology

Accounting Platform Sage Launches AI CoPilot to Boost Sector Offerings

The technology provider for small-to-medium business enterprise introduces generative AI tool and a unified cloud suite of construction products at its Las Vegas user conference on Feb. 28.

Read More
